courses.name: Introduction to Electrical & Electronics Engineering
courses.description: The purpose of this course is to provide a solid introduction to the freshmen of the fundamental principles of Electrical-Electronic Engineering. It lays the foundations of topics and techniques which will be covered in the four years of their Electrical-Electronic Engineering education.
courses.keywords: circuit analysis, Ohm's law, Kirchhoff's laws, capacitors, inductors, AC circuits, phasors, power, digital systems, binary, logic gates, signals, engineering ethics

content.topic: Introduction to Electrical Engineering - History, career paths, engineering design process
Fundamental Quantities - Charge, current, voltage, power, and energy
Circuit Elements - Resistors, voltage and current sources, switches
Ohm's Law and Kirchhoff's Laws - Series and parallel circuits
Circuit Analysis Techniques - Node voltage and mesh current methods
Thevenin and Norton Equivalents - Source transformation
Capacitors and Inductors - Energy storage elements, RC and RL circuits
First-Order Circuits - Natural and step response
Second-Order Circuits - RLC circuits, damping
AC Circuit Analysis - Phasors and impedance
AC Power - Average power, RMS values, power factor
Introduction to Digital Systems - Binary numbers, logic gates
Signals and Systems Overview - Time and frequency domain
Engineering Ethics and Professionalism - Review and future courses

courses.name: Analog Electronics I
courses.description: This course provides the students with an exposure to essential elements of analog electronics. The course concentrates on the introductory material associated with analog electronics and introduces students to fundamental electronic devices such as diodes, transistors and operational amplifiers. It develops on the notion of DC and small signal behavior. Students are shown how these devices are used in amplifier and switching circuits.
courses.keywords: semiconductors, diodes, BJT, MOSFET, amplifiers, biasing, small signal analysis, frequency response, operational amplifiers, transistor models

content.topic: Review of Circuit Analysis - Voltage dividers, current dividers, Thevenin equivalent
Semiconductor Physics - PN junction, energy bands, carrier drift and diffusion
Diode Characteristics - I-V characteristics, diode models, temperature effects
Diode Applications - Rectifier circuits, clipping and clamping circuits
Bipolar Junction Transistors (BJT) - Structure, operation modes, I-V characteristics
BJT Biasing - DC analysis, bias point selection, bias stability
Small Signal Analysis - Hybrid-pi model, voltage and current gain
BJT Amplifier Configurations - Common emitter, common base, common collector
MOSFET Fundamentals - Structure, operation, enhancement and depletion modes
MOSFET Biasing and Small Signal Analysis - DC operating point, small signal model
MOSFET Amplifiers - Common source, common gate, common drain configurations
Frequency Response - Bode plots, Miller effect, high-frequency models
Multi-Stage Amplifiers - Cascading, interstage coupling, overall gain
Introduction to Operational Amplifiers - Ideal op-amp, inverting and non-inverting amplifiers

courses.name: Analog Electronics II
courses.description: With this second course in Electronics students are shown how the electronic components and devices of the first course are further used in filter, amplifier and wave shaping circuits. Advanced topics in analog circuit design including differential amplifiers, feedback, and active filters.
courses.keywords: active filters, differential amplifiers, current mirrors, feedback, oscillators, waveform generators, voltage regulators, ADC, DAC, analog IC design

content.topic: Operational Amplifier Applications - Summing amplifier, difference amplifier, instrumentation amplifier
Active Filters I - First-order low-pass and high-pass filters
Active Filters II - Second-order filters, Butterworth and Chebyshev responses
Differential Amplifiers - Differential pairs, common-mode rejection ratio
Current Mirrors and Active Loads - Basic and cascode current mirrors
Output Stages - Class A, B, and AB amplifiers, push-pull configuration
Feedback Amplifiers - Negative feedback, types of feedback topologies
Stability and Compensation - Phase margin, gain margin, frequency compensation
Oscillators - Barkhausen criterion, Wien bridge, phase-shift oscillators
Waveform Generators - Multivibrators, 555 timer, function generators
Voltage Regulators - Linear regulators, switching regulators, voltage references
Data Converters - Digital-to-analog converters (DAC), analog-to-digital converters (ADC)
Analog Integrated Circuits - IC design considerations, analog layout basics
Advanced Topics and Review - Mixed-signal circuits, noise analysis

courses.name: Circuits and Systems I
courses.description: This course is addressed to the engineering sophomores who have successfully completed Electrical & Electronics Circuits I. The course provides the students with an exposure to essential principles and practices of fundamental electrical and electronic circuits.
courses.keywords: AC power, three-phase circuits, transformers, frequency response, two-port networks, Laplace transform, transfer functions, Fourier series, Fourier transform

content.topic: Review of Circuit Analysis - Mesh and nodal analysis, superposition
Network Theorems - Thevenin, Norton, maximum power transfer
Sinusoidal Steady-State Analysis - Phasors, impedance, admittance
AC Power Analysis - Instantaneous, average, and reactive power
Three-Phase Circuits - Wye and delta connections, balanced systems
Magnetically Coupled Circuits - Mutual inductance, transformers, ideal transformers
Frequency Response - Transfer functions, resonance, bandwidth
Two-Port Networks - Parameters (Z, Y, h, ABCD), interconnections
Laplace Transform I - Definition, properties, inverse transform
Laplace Transform II - Circuit analysis using Laplace transform
Transfer Functions - Poles and zeros, frequency response from transfer function
Fourier Series - Periodic signals, trigonometric and exponential Fourier series
Fourier Transform - Continuous-time Fourier transform, properties
Applications and Review - Filtering, spectral analysis

courses.name: Circuits and Systems II
courses.description: Advanced circuit analysis and systems theory. This course addresses the properties of continuous and discrete-time signals and systems, the analysis of signals and systems in the time and frequency domains, convolution, Fourier Series, and Fourier Transform.
courses.keywords: LTI systems, convolution, DTFT, z-transform, DFT, FFT, digital filters, sampling theorem, state-space analysis, discrete-time signals

content.topic: Signals and Systems Overview - Classification of signals, system properties
Linear Time-Invariant Systems - Impulse response, convolution integral
Convolution - Graphical convolution, properties of convolution
Fourier Series Representation - Convergence, Parseval's theorem
Fourier Transform Properties - Linearity, time-shifting, frequency-shifting
Filtering and Modulation - Ideal filters, amplitude modulation
Sampling Theorem - Nyquist rate, aliasing, reconstruction
Discrete-Time Signals - Sequences, discrete-time systems
Discrete-Time Fourier Transform - DTFT properties, frequency response
Z-Transform - Definition, properties, region of convergence
Z-Transform Applications - Transfer functions, system analysis
Discrete Fourier Transform - DFT, FFT algorithm
Digital Filter Design - FIR and IIR filters
State-Space Analysis - State variables, state equations

courses.name: Digital Logic Design
courses.description: Introduction to digital logic and computer hardware design. Topics include number systems, Boolean algebra, combinational and sequential logic circuits, and basic computer architecture.
courses.keywords: Boolean algebra, logic gates, combinational logic, Karnaugh maps, sequential logic, flip-flops, counters, finite state machines, VHDL, Verilog

content.topic: Number Systems - Binary, octal, hexadecimal, conversions
Binary Arithmetic - Addition, subtraction, 2's complement
Boolean Algebra - Laws, theorems, DeMorgan's theorem
Logic Gates - AND, OR, NOT, NAND, NOR, XOR gates
Combinational Logic I - Sum of products, product of sums
Karnaugh Maps - Simplification techniques, don't care conditions
Combinational Logic II - Multiplexers, demultiplexers, decoders, encoders
Arithmetic Circuits - Half adder, full adder, parallel adder, comparators
Sequential Logic Fundamentals - Latches and flip-flops
Registers and Counters - Shift registers, synchronous and asynchronous counters
Finite State Machines - Moore and Mealy machines, state diagrams
Memory Devices - RAM, ROM, programmable logic devices
Hardware Description Languages - Introduction to VHDL or Verilog
Digital System Design - Design methodology, testing

courses.name: Electromagnetic Fields and Waves
courses.description: Introduction to electromagnetic theory including electrostatics, magnetostatics, Maxwell's equations, and electromagnetic wave propagation. Applications to transmission lines and antennas.
courses.keywords: Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic waves, electrostatics, magnetostatics, Gauss's law, Faraday's law, wave propagation, transmission lines, Smith chart, antennas

content.topic: Vector Analysis - Coordinate systems, gradient, divergence, curl
Electrostatics I - Coulomb's law, electric field intensity
Electrostatics II - Gauss's law, electric potential
Conductors and Dielectrics - Boundary conditions, capacitance
Poisson's and Laplace's Equations - Solution methods
Magnetostatics I - Biot-Savart law, Ampere's law
Magnetostatics II - Magnetic flux density, magnetic materials
Time-Varying Fields - Faraday's law, induced EMF, transformers
Maxwell's Equations - Integral and differential forms, displacement current
Electromagnetic Wave Propagation - Wave equation, plane waves
Wave Reflection and Transmission - Boundary conditions, standing waves
Transmission Lines - Distributed parameters, characteristic impedance
Smith Chart and Impedance Matching - Reflection coefficient, VSWR
Antennas and Radiation - Hertzian dipole, antenna parameters

courses.name: Control Systems
courses.description: Analysis of linear control systems by differential equations and transfer function methods using Laplace transforms. Stability of closed loop systems. Routh-Hurwitz criterion, root-locus diagrams. System analysis in frequency domain. Bode and Nyquist plots. Nyquist stability criterion. Introduction to Design and Optimization. Matlab applications.
courses.keywords: feedback control, transfer functions, stability, Routh-Hurwitz, root locus, Bode plots, Nyquist plots, PID controller, state-space, MATLAB

content.topic: Introduction to Control Systems - Open-loop vs closed-loop control
Mathematical Models - Differential equations, transfer functions
Block Diagrams and Signal Flow Graphs - Reduction techniques, Mason's rule
Time Response Analysis - First and second-order systems, step response
Steady-State Errors - Error constants, system type
Stability Analysis - Routh-Hurwitz criterion
Root Locus Method I - Construction rules, breakaway points
Root Locus Method II - Design using root locus
Frequency Response I - Bode plots, gain and phase margins
Frequency Response II - Nyquist plots, Nyquist stability criterion
Controller Design I - PID controllers, tuning methods
Controller Design II - Lead and lag compensators
State-Space Methods - State equations, controllability, observability
Digital Control Systems - Discrete-time systems, z-domain analysis

courses.name: Communication Systems
courses.description: In this course, the basic concepts of communications engineering, the modulation techniques used in communication systems, and their performance analyses are introduced. Topics include analog and digital modulation, noise analysis, and information theory.
courses.keywords: modulation, AM, FM, digital modulation, ASK, FSK, PSK, QAM, noise, SNR, BER, channel capacity, Shannon theorem, error correction

content.topic: Introduction to Communication Systems - Information transmission, channel capacity
Signals and Spectra - Fourier analysis, power spectral density
Amplitude Modulation - AM, DSB-SC, SSB modulation and demodulation
Frequency Modulation - FM and PM, Carson's rule, bandwidth
Sampling and Quantization - Nyquist theorem, pulse code modulation
Baseband Digital Transmission - Line coding, ISI, eye diagrams
Digital Modulation I - ASK, FSK, PSK modulation schemes
Digital Modulation II - QAM, constellation diagrams
Noise in Communication Systems - White noise, noise figure
Performance Analysis - SNR, bit error rate, probability of error
Information Theory - Entropy, channel capacity, Shannon's theorem
Error Control Coding - Block codes, Hamming codes
Multiple Access Techniques - FDMA, TDMA, CDMA
Modern Communication Systems - Wireless, cellular, spread spectrum

courses.name: Power Systems
courses.description: Introduction to electric power generation, transmission, and distribution. Topics include power system components, three-phase circuits, transformers, generators, motors, and power flow analysis.
courses.keywords: three-phase systems, transformers, synchronous generators, induction motors, transmission lines, power flow, fault analysis, protection, power system stability

content.topic: Introduction to Power Systems - Generation, transmission, distribution
Three-Phase Systems Review - Balanced systems, per-phase analysis
Transformers I - Ideal transformers, voltage regulation
Transformers II - Equivalent circuits, three-phase transformers
Synchronous Generators I - Construction, EMF generation, armature reaction
Synchronous Generators II - Equivalent circuit, voltage regulation, parallel operation
Synchronous Motors - Equivalent circuit, torque, V-curves
Induction Motors I - Rotating magnetic field, slip, equivalent circuit
Induction Motors II - Torque-slip characteristics, starting methods
Transmission Lines I - Line parameters, resistance, inductance, capacitance
Transmission Lines II - Line models, ABCD parameters
Power Flow Analysis - Bus admittance matrix, Gauss-Seidel method
Fault Analysis - Symmetrical faults, per-unit system
Protection and Stability - Relaying, transient stability

courses.name: Microprocessors and Microcontrollers
courses.description: Introduction to microprocessor architecture, assembly language programming, and microcontroller applications. Topics include CPU architecture, instruction sets, memory interfacing, and I/O programming.
courses.keywords: microprocessor architecture, assembly language, instruction set, memory interfacing, I/O, interrupts, timers, serial communication, ADC, embedded systems

content.topic: Microprocessor Fundamentals - Architecture, fetch-decode-execute cycle
Number Systems and Data Representation - Binary arithmetic, ASCII, floating point
Assembly Language Programming I - Instruction set, addressing modes
Assembly Language Programming II - Subroutines, stack operations
Memory Organization - RAM, ROM, memory mapping, address decoding
Memory Interfacing - Bus timing, wait states, memory expansion
I/O Interfacing - Parallel and serial I/O, polling, interrupts
Interrupt Handling - Interrupt service routines, priority, vectored interrupts
Timers and Counters - Timer programming, pulse width modulation
Serial Communication - UART, SPI, I2C protocols
Analog-to-Digital Conversion - ADC types, interfacing, sampling
Microcontroller Applications I - Sensor interfacing, data acquisition
Microcontroller Applications II - Motor control, LCD interfacing
Embedded Systems Overview - Real-time systems, embedded C programming

courses.name: Digital Signal Processing
courses.description: Fundamentals of digital signal processing including discrete-time signals and systems, z-transforms, DFT/FFT, digital filter design, and DSP applications.
courses.keywords: discrete-time signals, z-transform, DFT, FFT, FIR filters, IIR filters, digital filter design, multirate processing, adaptive filters, DSP applications

content.topic: Introduction to DSP - Applications, sampling, quantization effects
Discrete-Time Signals and Systems - Classification, system properties
Linear Time-Invariant Systems - Convolution, difference equations
Z-Transform - Properties, inverse z-transform, transfer functions
Frequency Analysis - DTFT, frequency response
Discrete Fourier Transform - DFT definition, properties, circular convolution
Fast Fourier Transform - FFT algorithms, decimation-in-time, decimation-in-frequency
FIR Filter Design I - Linear phase, window method
FIR Filter Design II - Frequency sampling, optimal design
IIR Filter Design I - Analog filter approximations (Butterworth, Chebyshev)
IIR Filter Design II - Bilinear transformation, impulse invariance
Multirate Signal Processing - Decimation, interpolation, polyphase filters
Adaptive Filters - LMS algorithm, applications
DSP Applications - Speech processing, audio effects, image processing

courses.name: VLSI Design
courses.description: Introduction to Very Large Scale Integration (VLSI) design. Topics include MOS transistor theory, CMOS logic gates, design rules, layout, and simulation using CAD tools.
courses.keywords: VLSI, CMOS, MOS transistor, logic gates, layout, design rules, memory design, adders, multipliers, low power design, testability

content.topic: Introduction to VLSI - Moore's law, design abstraction levels, fabrication overview
MOS Transistor Theory - NMOS and PMOS operation, I-V characteristics
CMOS Inverter - Static characteristics, switching characteristics, power dissipation
Combinational Logic Design - Static CMOS gates, complex gates
Sequential Logic Design - Latches and flip-flops, timing analysis
Design Rules and Layout - Lambda rules, stick diagrams, layout techniques
Interconnect and Parasitic Effects - RC delay, capacitance models
Dynamic Logic - Precharge-evaluate logic, domino logic
Memory Design - SRAM cell design, sense amplifiers
Adder Architectures - Ripple carry, carry lookahead, carry select adders
Multiplier Design - Array multipliers, Wallace tree
Clock Distribution - Clock skew, H-tree structures
Low Power Design - Power estimation, power reduction techniques
Design for Testability - Scan chains, BIST, fault models

courses.name: Renewable Energy Systems
courses.description: Introduction to renewable energy technologies including solar, wind, hydroelectric, and other sustainable energy systems. Energy conversion, system design, and grid integration.
courses.keywords: solar energy, photovoltaics, wind energy, hydroelectric, biomass, geothermal, energy storage, power electronics, grid integration, sustainability

content.topic: Energy Overview - Global energy consumption, environmental impact, sustainability
Solar Radiation - Solar geometry, irradiance, solar angles
Photovoltaic Systems I - Solar cell physics, I-V characteristics, efficiency
Photovoltaic Systems II - PV array design, MPPT, inverters
Solar Thermal Systems - Collectors, concentrating systems, thermal storage
Wind Energy I - Wind resources, wind turbine types, power curves
Wind Energy II - Wind turbine generators, power electronics, control
Hydroelectric Power - Types of hydro plants, turbines, power calculation
Biomass and Biofuels - Biomass conversion, biogas, biodiesel
Geothermal Energy - Heat pumps, geothermal power plants
Energy Storage - Batteries, flywheels, pumped hydro, compressed air
Power Electronics for Renewable Energy - DC-DC converters, inverters, grid codes
Grid Integration - Distributed generation, microgrid, smart grid
Economics and Policy - Cost analysis, subsidies, carbon credits

courses.name: Advanced Electronics
courses.description: Advanced topics in analog and digital electronics including integrated circuit design, high-frequency circuits, noise analysis, and modern semiconductor devices.
courses.keywords: high-frequency amplifiers, noise analysis, oscillators, PLL, mixers, power amplifiers, RF circuits, data converters, switched-capacitor circuits, S-parameters

content.topic: Review of Semiconductor Devices - Diodes, BJT, MOSFET characteristics
Advanced Amplifier Topologies - Cascode amplifiers, differential amplifiers
High-Frequency Amplifiers - High-frequency transistor models, neutralization
Noise in Electronic Circuits - Noise sources, noise figure, low-noise design
Oscillator Design - Phase noise, crystal oscillators, VCOs
Phase-Locked Loops - PLL architecture, loop filters, applications
Mixers and Modulators - Frequency conversion, Gilbert cell
Power Amplifiers - Classes of operation, efficiency, linearity
Analog Integrated Circuit Design - Current mirrors, bandgap references
Advanced Data Converters - Pipeline ADC, delta-sigma converters
Switched-Capacitor Circuits - Sample-and-hold, SC filters
RF Circuit Design - Matching networks, S-parameters
Advanced Semiconductor Devices - HBT, HEMT, SiGe devices
Circuit Simulation and Layout - SPICE simulation, layout considerations

courses.name: Wireless Communications
courses.description: Principles of wireless communication systems including propagation, modulation, multiple access, cellular systems, and modern wireless standards.
courses.keywords: wireless propagation, fading, MIMO, OFDM, cellular systems, GSM, LTE, 5G, WiFi, Bluetooth, satellite communications, link budget

content.topic: Introduction to Wireless Communications - History, frequency bands, applications
Wireless Channel I - Path loss, shadowing, multipath fading
Wireless Channel II - Fading statistics, Rayleigh and Rician fading
Digital Modulation for Wireless - BPSK, QPSK, QAM, OFDM
Diversity Techniques - Time, frequency, and space diversity, MIMO
Multiple Access Techniques - FDMA, TDMA, CDMA, OFDMA
Spread Spectrum - Direct sequence, frequency hopping, PN sequences
Cellular Systems I - Cellular concept, frequency reuse, handoff
Cellular Systems II - GSM, CDMA, LTE architecture
5G and Beyond - Massive MIMO, mmWave, network slicing
Wireless LANs - IEEE 802.11 standards, WiFi
Bluetooth and IoT - Bluetooth architecture, Zigbee, LoRa
Satellite Communications - Orbits, link budget, satellite systems
Wireless System Design - Link budget, capacity planning, QoS

courses.name: Robotics and Automation
courses.description: Introduction to robotics including kinematics, dynamics, control, sensors, and actuators. Applications to industrial automation and autonomous systems.
courses.keywords: kinematics, dynamics, forward kinematics, inverse kinematics, Jacobian, trajectory planning, robot control, sensors, actuators, mobile robotics, SLAM

content.topic: Introduction to Robotics - History, robot types, applications
Spatial Descriptions - Position, orientation, homogeneous transformations
Forward Kinematics - DH parameters, link transformations
Inverse Kinematics - Analytical and numerical solutions, workspace
Velocity Kinematics - Jacobian matrix, singularities
Dynamics I - Lagrangian formulation, equations of motion
Dynamics II - Newton-Euler formulation, recursive algorithms
Trajectory Planning - Point-to-point, via points, path planning
Robot Control I - PID control, computed torque control
Robot Control II - Force control, impedance control
Sensors for Robotics - Encoders, IMU, vision sensors, force sensors
Actuators - DC motors, stepper motors, servo systems, pneumatics
Mobile Robotics - Locomotion, localization, SLAM basics
Industrial Automation - Robot programming, safety, future trends

courses.name: Optical Communications
courses.description: Fundamentals of optical fiber communications including light propagation, optical sources and detectors, fiber characteristics, and optical communication systems.
courses.keywords: optical fiber, light propagation, attenuation, dispersion, laser diode, LED, photodiode, WDM, DWDM, optical amplifiers, coherent detection

content.topic: Introduction to Optical Communications - History, advantages, system components
Optical Fiber Basics - Structure, total internal reflection, modes
Fiber Types and Characteristics - Single-mode, multimode, graded-index fibers
Signal Attenuation - Loss mechanisms, attenuation coefficient, fiber windows
Signal Dispersion - Modal dispersion, chromatic dispersion, polarization mode dispersion
Optical Sources I - LED and laser diode principles
Optical Sources II - Direct and external modulation, laser characteristics
Optical Detectors - Photodiode principles, PIN, APD, detector performance
Optical Receivers - Receiver architecture, noise, sensitivity
Digital Optical Communication Systems - Bit rate, link budget, system design
Wavelength Division Multiplexing - WDM principles, DWDM, optical amplifiers
Optical Amplifiers - EDFA, SOA, Raman amplifiers
Advanced Modulation Formats - Coherent detection, QPSK, QAM
Optical Networks - SONET/SDH, optical switches, future technologies

courses.name: Smart Grid Technologies
courses.description: Modern electric grid technologies including smart meters, demand response, distributed generation, energy storage, and grid communication systems.
courses.keywords: smart grid, smart meters, AMI, demand response, distributed generation, energy storage, microgrids, power electronics, cybersecurity, electric vehicles, V2G

content.topic: Introduction to Smart Grid - Concept, drivers, benefits, challenges
Traditional Power Grid - Generation, transmission, distribution review
Smart Grid Architecture - Infrastructure layers, components, standards
Advanced Metering Infrastructure - Smart meters, data management, privacy
Demand Response - Load management, pricing schemes, consumer participation
Distributed Energy Resources - DER types, grid integration, impact
Energy Storage Systems - Battery technologies, supercapacitors, grid-scale storage
Microgrids - Architecture, control, islanding, resilience
Power Electronics for Smart Grid - Inverters, converters, FACTS devices
Communication Technologies - PLC, wireless, fiber optics, protocols
Smart Grid Cybersecurity - Threats, encryption, authentication, standards
Electric Vehicles and V2G - EV charging, vehicle-to-grid integration
Grid Analytics - Big data, machine learning, predictive maintenance
Future Grid Technologies - Blockchain, AI, quantum computing applications

courses.name: Embedded Systems Design
courses.description: Advanced embedded systems including real-time operating systems, hardware-software co-design, embedded networking, and system-on-chip design.
courses.keywords: embedded systems, ARM, RTOS, real-time scheduling, hardware-software co-design, CAN bus, SoC, FPGA, IoT, edge computing, embedded security

content.topic: Embedded Systems Overview - Characteristics, applications, design challenges
Embedded Processors - ARM, AVR, PIC architectures, selection criteria
Memory Technologies - Flash, SRAM, DRAM, memory management
Embedded C Programming - Optimization, volatile, bit manipulation
Real-Time Systems - Real-time constraints, scheduling, priority
Real-Time Operating Systems I - RTOS concepts, tasks, kernel
RTOS II - Synchronization, semaphores, mutexes, message queues
Hardware-Software Co-Design - Partitioning, co-simulation, optimization
Embedded Networking - CAN bus, Ethernet, wireless protocols
Power Management - Low-power modes, dynamic voltage scaling, energy harvesting
System-on-Chip Design - SoC architecture, IP cores, buses
FPGA-Based Systems - FPGA architecture, HDL design, hardware acceleration
Embedded Security - Secure boot, encryption, trusted execution
IoT and Edge Computing - IoT protocols, edge processing, cloud integration
